text: Resolution adopted by the General Assembly on 19 December 2023
[on the report of the Third Committee (A/78/473, para. 24)]
78/181.	Improvement of the situation of women and girls in rural areas
The General Assembly,

Recalling its resolutions 56/129 of 19 December 2001, 58/146 of 22 December 2003, 60/138 of 16 December 2005, 62/136 of 18 December 2007, 64/140 of 18 December 2009, 66/129 of 19 December 2011, 68/139 of 18 December 2013, 70/132 of 17 December 2015, 72/148 of 19 December 2017, 74/126 of 18 December 2019, and 76/140 of 16 December 2021,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* its resolutions 56/129 of 19 December 2001, 58/146 of 22 December 2003, 60/138 of 16 December 2005, 62/136 of 18 December 2007, 64/140 of 18 December 2009, 66/129 of 19 December 2011, 68/139 of 18 December 2013, 70/132 of 17 December 2015, 72/148 of 19 December 2017, 74/126 of 18 December 2019, and 76/140 of 16 December 2021,

text: Reaffirming the obligation of all States to promote and protect all human rights and fundamental freedoms, and also that all forms of discrimination, including discrimination against women and girls, are contrary to the Charter of the United Nations, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and other human rights instruments,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* the obligation of {{all States}} to promote and protect all human rights and fundamental freedoms, and also that all forms of discrimination, including discrimination against women and girls, are contrary to the Charter of the United Nations, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and other human rights instruments,

text: Reaffirming also the commitment made to gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls, including those in rural areas, contained in the outcome documents of relevant international conferences and summits, in particular the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action adopted at the Fourth World Conference on Women, the outcome of the twenty-third special session of the General Assembly entitled “Women 2000: gender equality, development and peace for the twenty-first century” and the outcome document of the high-level plenary meeting of the General Assembly known as the World Conference on Indigenous Peoples, and recalling other instruments, as appropriate, such as the United Nations Declaration on the Right to Development,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming also* the commitment made to gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls, including those in rural areas, contained in the outcome documents of relevant international conferences and summits, in particular the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action adopted at the Fourth World Conference on Women, the outcome of the twenty-third special session of the {{General Assembly}} entitled “Women 2000: gender equality, development and peace for the twenty-first century” and the outcome document of the high-level plenary meeting of the {{General Assembly}} known as the World Conference on Indigenous Peoples, and *recalling* other instruments, as appropriate, such as the United Nations Declaration on the Right to Development,

text: Reaffirming further the outcome document of the United Nations summit for the adoption of the post-2015 development agenda, entitled “Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development”, and the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming further* the outcome document of the United Nations summit for the adoption of the post-2015 development agenda, entitled “Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development”, and the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development,

text: Recalling that the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development addresses the need to achieve gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls, in order to ensure that no one is left behind, and that the systematic mainstreaming of a gender perspective in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda is crucial,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* that the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development addresses the need to achieve gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls, in order to ensure that no one is left behind, and that the systematic mainstreaming of a gender perspective in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda is crucial,

text: Recognizing that the achievement of full human potential and of sustainable development is not possible if one half of humanity continues to be denied its full human rights and opportunities,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that the achievement of full human potential and of sustainable development is not possible if one half of humanity continues to be denied its full human rights and opportunities,

text: Taking note of the Secretary-General’s High-level Panel on Women’s Economic Empowerment,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: High-level Panel on Women’s Economic Empowerment
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: High-level Panel on Women’s Economic Empowerment

textWithHighlights: *Taking note* of the {{Secretary-General}}’s {{High-level Panel on Women’s Economic Empowerment}},

text: Recognizing its resolution 76/300 of 28 July 2022 on the human right to a clean, healthy and sustainable environment,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* its resolution 76/300 of 28 July 2022 on the human right to a clean, healthy and sustainable environment,

text: Recognizing also the threat that environmental degradation, climate change, biodiversity loss, desertification and unsustainable development pose to the enjoyment of all human rights by present and future generations, in particular women and girls,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing also* the threat that environmental degradation, climate change, biodiversity loss, desertification and unsustainable development pose to the enjoyment of all human rights by present and future generations, in particular women and girls,

text: Acknowledging that achieving gender equality, the empowerment of all women and girls and women’s full, equal effective and meaningful participation and decision-making in the context of climate change, environmental degradation and disaster risk reduction is essential for achieving sustainable development,
textWithHighlights: *Acknowledging* that achieving gender equality, the empowerment of all women and girls and women’s full, equal effective and meaningful participation and decision-making in the context of climate change, environmental degradation and disaster risk reduction is essential for achieving sustainable development,

text: Recalling the agreed conclusions of the Commission on the Status of Women at its sixty-second session and its priority theme “Challenges and opportunities in achieving gender equality and the empowerment of rural women and girls”, which was reviewed at the sixty-seventh session of the Commission on the Status of Women,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Commission on the Status of Women

textWithHighlights: *Recalling* the agreed conclusions of the {{Commission on the Status of Women}} at its sixty-second session and its priority theme “Challenges and opportunities in achieving gender equality and the empowerment of rural women and girls”, which was reviewed at the sixty-seventh session of the {{Commission on the Status of Women}},

text: Stressing the need for Governments to take measures to support the rights, well-being and resilience of women and girls living in rural or remote areas and on islands,
textWithHighlights: *Stressing* the need for {{Governments}} to take measures to support the rights, well-being and resilience of women and girls living in rural or remote areas and on islands,

text: Recognizing that progress on the achievement of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls, in particular in rural areas, has been held back owing to the persistence of historical and structural barriers and unequal power relations between women and men, poverty and inequalities and disadvantages in access to resources and opportunities that limit women’s and girls’ capabilities, growing gaps in equality of opportunity, discriminatory laws, policies, attitudes, harmful customary and contemporary practices and gender stereotypes and negative social norms, as well as women’s and girls’ unequal share of unpaid care work and precarious working conditions experienced by many women engaged in paid care work, and taking into consideration the impacts of armed conflicts on rural women and girls and the spiralling effects of the cost-of-living crisis, climate and environment emergencies and the continuing effects of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic that have compounded underlying and persistent gender gaps and inequality,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that progress on the achievement of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls, in particular in rural areas, has been held back owing to the persistence of historical and structural barriers and unequal power relations between women and men, poverty and inequalities and disadvantages in access to resources and opportunities that limit women’s and girls’ capabilities, growing gaps in equality of opportunity, discriminatory laws, policies, attitudes, harmful customary and contemporary practices and gender stereotypes and negative social norms, as well as women’s and girls’ unequal share of unpaid care work and precarious working conditions experienced by many women engaged in paid care work, and *taking into consideration* the impacts of armed conflicts on rural women and girls and the spiralling effects of the cost-of-living crisis, climate and environment emergencies and the continuing effects of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic that have compounded underlying and persistent gender gaps and inequality,

text: Expressing its deep concern that discrimination and violence against women and girls, including those in rural areas, continue to occur in all parts of the world and that all forms of violence and discrimination, including multiple and intersecting forms of discrimination, that women and girls face are impediments to the development of their full potential as equal partners with men and boys in all aspects of life, as well as obstacles to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals,
textWithHighlights: *Expressing its deep concern* that discrimination and violence against women and girls, including those in rural areas, continue to occur in all parts of the world and that all forms of violence and discrimination, including multiple and intersecting forms of discrimination, that women and girls face are impediments to the development of their full potential as equal partners with men and boys in all aspects of life, as well as obstacles to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals,

text: Expressing its deep concern also that, while agriculture continues to be the most important employment sector for women in low-income and lower-middle-income countries, with an estimated 25 per cent of employed women around the world working in agriculture, they are relegated to informal, low-paid, low-skilled, labour-intensive and vulnerable jobs, at risk of exploitation and abuse and disproportionately affected by hunger, malnutrition, food insecurity and poverty, including the feminization of poverty, in part as a result of gender inequality and discrimination,
textWithHighlights: *Expressing its deep concern also* that, while agriculture continues to be the most important employment sector for women in low-income and lower-middle-income countries, with an estimated 25 per cent of employed women around the world working in agriculture, they are relegated to informal, low-paid, low-skilled, labour-intensive and vulnerable jobs, at risk of exploitation and abuse and disproportionately affected by hunger, malnutrition, food insecurity and poverty, including the feminization of poverty, in part as a result of gender inequality and discrimination,

text: Expressing its deep concern further that while women contribute more than 50 per cent of the food produced worldwide, they account for 70 per cent of the world’s hungry, that a widening gender gap in food insecurity, which grew from 1.7 per cent in 2019 to 4.3 in 2021, with 31.9 per cent of women in a state of moderate or severe food insecurity compared with 27.6 per cent of men, indicates that women around the world and across regions are more food-insecure than men,
textWithHighlights: *Expressing its deep concern further* that while women contribute more than 50 per cent of the food produced worldwide, they account for 70 per cent of the world’s hungry, that a widening gender gap in food insecurity, which grew from 1.7 per cent in 2019 to 4.3 in 2021, with 31.9 per cent of women in a state of moderate or severe food insecurity compared with 27.6 per cent of men, indicates that women around the world and across regions are more food-insecure than men,

text: Expressing concern that many rural women continue to be economically and socially disadvantaged because of their limited access to economic resources and opportunities and their limited access or lack of access to quality education, health-care services, justice, land, sustainable and time- and labour-saving infrastructure and technology, water and sanitation and other resources, as well as to credit, extension services and agricultural inputs, and expressing concern also about their exclusion from planning and decision-making and their disproportionate share of unpaid care and domestic work,
textWithHighlights: *Expressing concern* that many rural women continue to be economically and socially disadvantaged because of their limited access to economic resources and opportunities and their limited access or lack of access to quality education, health-care services, justice, land, sustainable and time- and labour-saving infrastructure and technology, water and sanitation and other resources, as well as to credit, extension services and agricultural inputs, and *expressing concern* also about their exclusion from planning and decision-making and their disproportionate share of unpaid care and domestic work,

text: Emphasizing that rural women’s poverty is directly related to the absence of economic opportunities and autonomy and the lack of access to economic and productive resources, quality education and support services and of women’s participation in the decision-making process, and recognizing that rural women’s poverty and lack of empowerment as well as their exclusion from social and economic policies can place them at increased risk of violence that can impede their social and economic development, as well as the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals,
textWithHighlights: *Emphasizing* that rural women’s poverty is directly related to the absence of economic opportunities and autonomy and the lack of access to economic and productive resources, quality education and support services and of women’s participation in the decision-making process, and *recognizing* that rural women’s poverty and lack of empowerment as well as their exclusion from social and economic policies can place them at increased risk of violence that can impede their social and economic development, as well as the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals,

text: Recognizing that, despite gains in providing access to quality education, rural girls are still more likely than rural boys to remain excluded from education and that among the gender-specific barriers to girls’ equal enjoyment of their right to education are the feminization of poverty, child labour undertaken by girls, child, early and forced marriage, female genital mutilation, early and repeat pregnancies, all forms of violence, including gender-based violence, abuse and harassment on the way to and from and at school, in their technology-mediated environment, the lack of safe and adequate sanitation facilities, including for menstrual hygiene management, the disproportionate share of unpaid care and domestic work performed by girls and gender stereotypes and negative social norms that lead families and communities to place less value on the education of girls than that of boys and may influence the decision of parents to allow girls to attend school,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that, despite gains in providing access to quality education, rural girls are still more likely than rural boys to remain excluded from education and that among the gender-specific barriers to girls’ equal enjoyment of their right to education are the feminization of poverty, child labour undertaken by girls, child, early and forced marriage, female genital mutilation, early and repeat pregnancies, all forms of violence, including gender-based violence, abuse and harassment on the way to and from and at school, in their technology-mediated environment, the lack of safe and adequate sanitation facilities, including for menstrual hygiene management, the disproportionate share of unpaid care and domestic work performed by girls and gender stereotypes and negative social norms that lead families and communities to place less value on the education of girls than that of boys and may influence the decision of parents to allow girls to attend school,

text: Recognizing also the Voluntary Guidelines on the Responsible Governance of Tenure of Land, Fisheries and Forests in the Context of National Food Security and the Principles for Responsible Investment in Agriculture and Food Systems, endorsed by the Committee on World Food Security, which embrace gender equality as one of the main guiding principles of implementation in order to help to address the ongoing disparities with regard to access to and control of land and other natural resources,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing also* the Voluntary Guidelines on the Responsible Governance of Tenure of Land, Fisheries and Forests in the Context of National Food Security and the Principles for Responsible Investment in Agriculture and Food Systems, endorsed by the {{Committee on World Food Security}}, which embrace gender equality as one of the main guiding principles of implementation in order to help to address the ongoing disparities with regard to access to and control of land and other natural resources,
uncertainties: Classified the Committee on World Food Security (CFS) as a UN System entity; while hosted by FAO/IFAD/WFP, it is not explicitly listed in the provided entity list.

text: Deeply concerned that climate change poses a challenge to poverty eradication and the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals, threatens food security and increases the risks of famine and adversely impacts the health and well-being of rural women and their families, and that rural women and girls, especially in developing countries, are disproportionately affected by the impacts of desertification, deforestation, sand and dust storms, natural disasters, persistent drought, extreme weather events, sea level rise, coastal erosion and ocean acidification and often have limited capacities to adapt to climate change,
textWithHighlights: *Deeply concerned* that climate change poses a challenge to poverty eradication and the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals, threatens food security and increases the risks of famine and adversely impacts the health and well-being of rural women and their families, and that rural women and girls, especially in {{developing countries}}, are disproportionately affected by the impacts of desertification, deforestation, sand and dust storms, natural disasters, persistent drought, extreme weather events, sea level rise, coastal erosion and ocean acidification and often have limited capacities to adapt to climate change,

text: Recognizing that women and girls in rural areas may be particularly vulnerable to violence because of multidimensional poverty and lack of access to social care and protection services and, as applicable, employment opportunities, as well as negative social norms,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that women and girls in rural areas may be particularly vulnerable to violence because of multidimensional poverty and lack of access to social care and protection services and, as applicable, employment opportunities, as well as negative social norms,

text: Takes note of the report of the Secretary-General;
textWithHighlights: *Takes note* of the report of the {{Secretary-General}};

text: Urges Member States, in collaboration with the organizations of the United Nations system and civil society, as appropriate, to continue their efforts to implement the outcome of and to ensure an integrated and coordinated follow-up to the relevant United Nations conferences and summits, including their reviews, and to attach greater importance to the improvement of the situation of rural women and girls in their national, regional and global development strategies by, inter alia:

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: organizations of the United Nations system

textWithHighlights: *Urges* <<Member States>>, in collaboration with the {{organizations of the United Nations system}} and {{civil society}}, as appropriate, to continue their efforts to implement the outcome of and to ensure an integrated and coordinated follow-up to the relevant United Nations conferences and summits, including their reviews, and to attach greater importance to the improvement of the situation of rural women and girls in their national, regional and global development strategies by, inter alia:
uncertainties: This paragraph appears to introduce subparagraphs (ending with a colon), so concrete deliverables may follow in subsequent lines; none are extracted here from this introductory clause.

text: Creating an enabling environment for improving their situation and ensuring systematic attention to their needs, priorities and contributions, as well as gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls, including through enhanced cooperation and a gender perspective, and the full and equal participation of all women in the development, implementation and follow-up of macroeconomic policies, including development policies and programmes and poverty eradication strategies, including poverty reduction strategy papers, where they exist, aimed at implementing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Enabling environment for gender equality and empowerment
Full and equal participation of women in macroeconomic policymaking

textWithHighlights: Creating an [[enabling environment]] for improving their situation and ensuring systematic attention to their needs, priorities and contributions, as well as gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls, including through enhanced cooperation and a gender perspective, and the [[full and equal participation]] of all women in the development, implementation and follow-up of macroeconomic policies, including development policies and programmes and poverty eradication strategies, including poverty reduction strategy papers, where they exist, aimed at implementing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development;
uncertainties: Assignees are inherited from the parent clause (“Urges Member States…”). Deliverables are somewhat broad; categorized as 'policy' given their governance/process nature. Not extracting “ensuring systematic attention” to stay conservative.

text: Encouraging Member States to consider adopting and pursuing national financial inclusion strategies and gender-responsive strategies to end the structural barriers to women’s equal access to economic resources and to expand peer learning, experience-sharing and capacity-building in rural areas;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: national financial inclusion strategies
gender-responsive strategies
peer learning
experience-sharing
capacity-building

textWithHighlights: Encouraging <<Member States>> to consider adopting and pursuing [[national financial inclusion strategies]] and [[gender-responsive strategies]] to end the structural barriers to women’s equal access to economic resources and to expand [[peer learning]], [[experience-sharing]] and [[capacity-building]] in rural areas;
uncertainties: Operative verb and assignee are inherited from the parent clause (“Urges Member States … by, inter alia:”). Classified “peer learning” and “experience-sharing” as information_sharing; these could also contribute to capacity building, but a separate capacity-building item is explicitly mentioned.

text: Supporting the important role of civil society in promoting the realization and fulfilment of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of all women, including rural women;
textWithHighlights: Supporting the important role of {{civil society}} in promoting the realization and fulfilment of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of all women, including rural women;

text: Taking steps in the design, implementation and pursuit of fiscal policies and gender-responsive budgeting to promote gender equality and the empowerment of rural women and girls;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: fiscal policies
gender-responsive budgeting

textWithHighlights: Taking steps in the design, implementation and pursuit of [[fiscal policies]] and [[gender-responsive budgeting]] to promote gender equality and the empowerment of rural women and girls;

text: Pursuing the political and socioeconomic empowerment of rural women and supporting their full and equal participation in decision-making at all levels, including through affirmative action, where appropriate, including by promoting and protecting the right to vote and to be elected and the right to freedom of expression, peaceful assembly and association, and through support for women’s and farmers’ organizations in which subsistence and smallholder women farmers are members, labour unions, cooperatives or other associations and civil society groups promoting rural women’s rights;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: affirmative action policies

textWithHighlights: Pursuing the political and socioeconomic empowerment of rural women and supporting their full and equal participation in decision-making at all levels, including through [[affirmative action]], where appropriate, including by promoting and protecting the right to vote and to be elected and the right to freedom of expression, peaceful assembly and association, and through support for women’s and farmers’ organizations in which subsistence and smallholder women farmers are members, labour unions, cooperatives or other associations and {{civil society}} groups promoting rural women’s rights;
uncertainties: This subparagraph inherits the operative verb ('Urges') and the assignee (Member States) from the parent clause; they do not appear in the text itself, so they are not highlighted. 'Affirmative action' is interpreted as a policy deliverable; other elements (e.g., promoting and protecting rights, support for organizations) are considered too broad/vague to mark as concrete deliverables.

text: Promoting consultation with and the participation of rural women and, as appropriate, girls, including those who are Indigenous, those with disabilities and older women, through their organizations and networks, in the design, development and implementation of and follow-up to programmes and strategies for gender equality, the empowerment of women and rural development;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Consultations with rural women and girls in programme and strategy processes

textWithHighlights: Promoting [[consultation]] with and the participation of rural women and, as appropriate, girls, including those who are Indigenous, those with disabilities and older women, through their organizations and networks, in the design, development and implementation of and follow-up to programmes and strategies for gender equality, the empowerment of women and rural development;
uncertainties: Classified 'consultation' as deliverable type 'meeting'; 'participation' was not marked as a separate deliverable due to lack of a fitting category.

text: Ensuring that the perspectives of rural women and girls are taken into account and that rural women fully, meaningfully and equally participate in the design, implementation, follow-up and evaluation of policies and activities related to conflict prevention, the mitigation of post-conflict situations, peace mediation, the impacts of climate change and emergencies, including natural disasters, humanitarian assistance, peacebuilding and post-conflict reconstruction, and taking appropriate measures to eliminate all forms of violence and discrimination against rural women and girls in this regard;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Participation of rural women in policy and activity design, implementation, follow-up and evaluation
Elimination of violence and discrimination against rural women and girls
deliverables.deliverable: eliminate all forms of violence and discrimination

textWithHighlights: Ensuring that the perspectives of rural women and girls are taken into account and that rural women fully, meaningfully and equally [[participate]] in the design, implementation, follow-up and evaluation of policies and activities related to conflict prevention, the mitigation of post-conflict situations, peace mediation, the impacts of climate change and emergencies, including natural disasters, humanitarian assistance, peacebuilding and post-conflict reconstruction, and taking appropriate measures to [[eliminate all forms of violence and discrimination]] against rural women and girls in this regard;
uncertainties: The operative verb and assignee are inherited from the parent clause (“Urges Member States...”); thus no verb appears in this subparagraph. Consideration: whether to also extract “taken into account” (perspectives of rural women and girls) as a separate deliverable; it was omitted to avoid redundancy with the participation deliverable.

text: Integrating a gender perspective into the design, implementation and evaluation of and follow-up to development policies, plans and programmes, including budget policies, where lacking, ensuring coordination between line ministries, gender policymakers, gender machineries and other relevant government organizations and institutions with gender expertise, and paying increased attention to the needs of rural women and girls to ensure that they benefit from policies and programmes adopted in all spheres and that the disproportionate number of rural women living in poverty is reduced;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Integrate gender perspective into development policies and programmes
Ensure coordination between ministries and gender institutions on gender policy

textWithHighlights: [[Integrating a gender perspective]] into the design, implementation and evaluation of and follow-up to development policies, plans and programmes, including budget policies, where lacking, [[ensuring coordination]] between line ministries, gender policymakers, gender machineries and other relevant government organizations and institutions with gender expertise, and paying increased attention to the needs of rural women and girls to ensure that they benefit from policies and programmes adopted in all spheres and that the disproportionate number of rural women living in poverty is reduced;
uncertainties: Classification of "ensuring coordination" as a policy deliverable vs. strategy could be interpreted differently.

text: Mainstreaming a gender perspective in decision-making processes and the governance of natural resources, leveraging the participation and influence of women in managing the sustainable use of natural resources, and enhancing the capacities of Governments, civil society and development partners to better understand and address gender issues in the management and governance of natural resources;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Mainstream gender perspective in natural resource governance
Enhance capacities to address gender issues in natural resource management

textWithHighlights: [[Mainstreaming a gender perspective]] in decision-making processes and the governance of natural resources, leveraging the participation and influence of women in managing the sustainable use of natural resources, and [[enhancing the capacities]] of {{Governments}}, {{civil society}} and development partners to better understand and address gender issues in the management and governance of natural resources;
uncertainties: Assignee and operative verb are inherited from the parent 'Urges Member States...'. Treated 'Mainstreaming a gender perspective' as a policy deliverable and 'enhancing the capacities' as capacity building; 'leveraging the participation and influence of women' was considered too vague to mark as a deliverable. 'Governments' was normalized to 'Member States' as a mentioned entity; 'development partners' not mapped to an entity list item.

text: Enacting and implementing policies to eradicate poverty and reduce inequalities by promoting sustainable livelihoods, decent work and income security for women in rural areas to enhance the well-being and resilience of all rural women and girls, including women migrant workers;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Policies to eradicate poverty and reduce inequalities

textWithHighlights: Enacting and implementing [[policies]] to eradicate poverty and reduce inequalities by promoting sustainable livelihoods, decent work and income security for women in rural areas to enhance the well-being and resilience of all rural women and girls, including women migrant workers;
uncertainties: Operative verb and assignee are inherited from the parent clause ('Urges Member States ...'). The UN system and civil society are noted in the parent as collaborators, not treated here as assignees.

text: Implementing effective, high-impact, quality-assured, people-centred, gender- and disability-responsive and evidence-based interventions to meet the health needs of rural women and girls, particularly those in vulnerable situations, throughout their life course;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Implementation of evidence-based health interventions

textWithHighlights: Implementing effective, high-impact, quality-assured, people-centred, gender- and disability-responsive and [[evidence-based interventions]] to meet the health needs of rural women and girls, particularly those in vulnerable situations, throughout their life course;
uncertainties: Deliverable type is somewhat ambiguous: implementing health interventions is concrete service delivery but not strictly humanitarian; classified here as humanitarian_assistance as the closest fit.

text: Strengthening measures, including resource generation, to improve women’s health, including maternal health, by addressing the specific health, nutrition and basic needs of rural women and taking concrete measures to enhance and provide access to the highest attainable standards of physical and mental health for women of all ages in rural areas, as well as quality, affordable and universally accessible primary health care and support services, including prenatal and postnatal health care, emergency obstetric care, family planning, information and education, increasing knowledge, awareness and support for the elimination of harmful practices and the prevention, treatment and care of sexually transmitted infections, including HIV, and ensuring universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development, the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Resource generation
Primary health care and support services
deliverables.deliverable: primary health care and support services

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Prenatal and postnatal health care
Emergency obstetric care
Family planning services
Health information and education
Increase knowledge and awareness on harmful practices
Prevention, treatment and care of STIs (including HIV)
deliverables.deliverable: prevention, treatment and care of sexually transmitted infections

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights
deliverables.deliverable: universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights

textWithHighlights: Strengthening measures, including [[resource generation]], to improve women’s health, including maternal health, by addressing the specific health, nutrition and basic needs of rural women and taking concrete measures to enhance and provide access to the highest attainable standards of physical and mental health for women of all ages in rural areas, as well as quality, affordable and universally accessible [[primary health care and support services]], including [[prenatal and postnatal health care]], [[emergency obstetric care]], [[family planning]], [[information and education]], [[increasing knowledge, awareness]] and support for the elimination of harmful practices and the [[prevention, treatment and care of sexually transmitted infections]], including HIV, and ensuring [[universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights]] in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development, the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences;
uncertainties: This subparagraph inherits the verb and assignee from the parent clause (“Urges Member States…”). Categorizing health service delivery (e.g., primary health care, STI treatment) under “humanitarian_assistance” is approximate, as these are not strictly emergency actions; “policy” was chosen for universal access to SRHR due to its alignment with rights and framework implementation.

text: Strengthening the prevention, treatment and care of infections, such as HIV, in rural areas, by providing accessible information, social care services and infrastructure;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Accessible information
Social care services
Infrastructure

textWithHighlights: Strengthening the prevention, treatment and care of infections, such as HIV, in rural areas, by providing [[accessible information]], [[social care services]] and [[infrastructure]];
uncertainties: Operative verb and assignee are inherited from the parent clause (“Urges Member States…”). Classification of “social care services” as humanitarian_assistance is approximate; it could be considered service delivery outside emergency contexts.

text: Taking appropriate measures to ensure that women’s and girls’ disproportionate share of unpaid care and domestic work, as well as contributions to on-farm and off-farm production, is recognized, including by fully recognizing and valuing unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family, and to promote nationally appropriate policies and initiatives supporting the reconciliation of work and family life and the equal sharing of responsibilities between men and women with a view to reducing and equitably distributing such unpaid work, including through, inter alia, the provision of infrastructure, technology and public services, such as water and sanitation, renewable energy, transport and information and communications technology, as well as addressing the need for accessible, affordable and quality childcare and care facilities in rural areas;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Social protection policies
Policies supporting work–family reconciliation
deliverables.deliverable: policies and initiatives supporting the reconciliation of work and family life

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Provision of infrastructure
